{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3496451,"name":"Jaco Xia","username":"jxia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/b77776/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-30T08:07:02.978Z","cooked":"

What is the minimum overlap between elevator stages? My team is running a one stage elevator with roughly a 30" travel distance. At max extension, there is around 4" of overlap, but the elevator isn’t under heavy load (excluding unpredicted collisions). All of our stages are also 1/16" wall thickness 2x1. We are using the WCP inline clamping bearing block.

Would this be okay? Would the bearing blocks fail? We’ve had a team near us have their bolts shear last year so it’s troubling us.

image410×1458 116 KB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-30T08:07:02.978Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":94,"reads":337,"readers_count":336,"score":557.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":484263,"topic_slug":"minimum-elevator-overlap","display_username":"Jaco Xia","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60895,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"694"},"post_url":"/t/minimum-elevator-overlap/484263/1","custom_user_title":"694","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3496465,"name":"Vaughn Khouri","username":"CyberClone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-30T10:20:53.864Z","cooked":"

4 inches of overlap at this extension is a very, very bad idea. I’d say you want 6-6.5 minimum.

We’re sitting at a bit over 8 this year, and it’s not our favorite. Robots are tall this year, superstructures are gonna be a big failure point.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-30T10:20:53.864Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":314,"readers_count":313,"score":137.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":484263,"topic_slug":"minimum-elevator-overlap","display_username":"Vaughn Khouri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52319,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/minimum-elevator-overlap/484263/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3496572,"name":"Charlie Peskay","username":"Techno-1155","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/techno-1155/{size}/200332_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-30T13:47:10.899Z","cooked":"

Stage overlap is really important for preventing failures at max extension, especially if you think your robot will be at max extension frequently. If you can, I’d aim for at least 6-8” of overlap.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-30T13:47:10.899Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":85.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":484263,"topic_slug":"minimum-elevator-overlap","display_username":"Charlie Peskay","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53969,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1155A"},"post_url":"/t/minimum-elevator-overlap/484263/3","custom_user_title":"1155A","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3496582,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-30T14:02:18.664Z","cooked":"
jxia:

excluding unpredicted collisions

There is such a large lever here… Especially with 4" of overlap.

Small bumps could easily send forces of hundreds of pounds through the lower blocks, all which need to be taken up by a few small bolts and passed through tiny contact patches with the bearings… The bearing/aluminum interface will spike to some crazy pressures. Bearings will likely get damaged over time, tubes will get deformed.

If you want 4" of overlap you are going to need to step away from COTS roller bearing blocks and over to larger flat bearing surfaces like delrin slides.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-30T14:05:08.233Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":229,"readers_count":228,"score":85.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":484263,"topic_slug":"minimum-elevator-overlap","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/minimum-elevator-overlap/484263/4","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3496588,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-30T14:08:58.800Z","cooked":"

The answer is - “It depends”. There is no hard and fast rule, because it is a very complicated engineering problem.

A better way to look at this is to ask “what is the max overlap we can realistically get?” This gets you the best safety factor.

A practical way to look at it is to plan to work at the overlap you’ve found is necessary. In your case, 4"? But have a fall back plan. Try the 4". See if you break it. Have your backup plan ready to go. It could be as simple as limiting the travel in code to improve the overlap.

To have that ability, engineer your mechanisms with extra reach so that you can add the overlap in if you need to. If you end up not needing it, you can consider iterating the design to reduce lengths and save weight.

FIRST is often a trade off. Back-of-the-napkin calculations can only take you so far, and then you have to fall back onto testing. If you’re a team that can’t afford (either financially or because of time constraints) to iterate a bunch of times, then design to the safe side with backup plans and simply accept that your mechanism is not going to be the most perfect efficient mechanism you can have.

Don’t let perfect be the enemy of good, and don’t let it slow your design process. If you have something you think might work, it’s probably time to build it and find out.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-01-30T14:09:45.607Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":212,"readers_count":211,"score":192.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":484263,"topic_slug":"minimum-elevator-overlap","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/minimum-elevator-overlap/484263/5","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":7}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3496596,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-30T14:28:50.414Z","cooked":"

One simple way to look at this is your upper stage is a lever with the pivot at the top bearing block. With, for example, 40” above the pivot and 4” below it, any force applied to the top of the stage will be multiplied 10x at the bearings.

Now imagine you have 5kg at the top of your elevator and experience even just a 10g deceleration (say running into something). F=ma says 50N of force, multiplied by 10 is 500N of force, all delivered to your lower stage via the very small contact patch of (likely) 4 small bearings.
